title: Doctor blamed pet spray for him squeezing nurse’s backside
text:
Dr Colin Gelder claims to have suffered a reaction to pet calming spray (Picture: Cavendish Press)

A doctor who squeezed a nurse’s bottom as she bent over the medicines trolley was suffering a ‘euphoric’ reaction to a pet calming spray, a tribunal heard.

Dr Colin Gelder, 59, claimed he groped the woman after herbal fumes from a Pet Remedy plug diffuser mixed adversely with his hayfever medication and made him ‘feel like Superman’.

The nurse, 55, told the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service she felt ‘dirty and cheap’ after the incident.

When she told the senior physician the only person allowed to touch her bottom was her husband, he replied that he was ‘a very lucky man’ and ‘didn’t even have the decency to apologise’, she said.

Later during the same shift, Dr Gelder a Consultant Respiratory Physician at University Hospital in Coventry, told another female colleague who came to reprimand him: ‘You’re sexy when you are cross.’

Advertisement

The doctor admitted the incidents, but blamed his behaviour on inhaling the herb Valerian which is used in Pet Remedy products to calm his dogs when they get anxious.

Dr Gelder and his wife at the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service in Manchester (Picture: Cavendish Press)

The tribunal heard the incident occurred during her morning rounds in September 2017.

Alan Taylor, for the General Medical Council, said: ‘She was at her drug trolley and was so focused on doing her round, she did not notice any other staff around.

‘The next minute, as she was leaning over the trolley, she felt a hard squeeze to the left buttock and she turned around and saw Dr Gelder looking directly at her and smiling.’

Mr Taylor said the second incident took place later during the same shift.

The tribunal heard how a ‘medical report notes Valerian does not alter behaviour’ and ‘neither does exposure to Pet Remedy or any other such treatment’.

But the panel was told the senior doctor ‘does not accept this’.

Dr Gelder, who faces being struck off after 35 years in medicine, said: ‘It remains my mitigation that this wholly bizarre behaviour is explained by my exposure to the product.

‘This does not excuse my behaviour but my behaviour was so out of character that day.’

He denied his behaviour was sexually motivated, instead saying he found it ‘a really funny opportunity for a practical joke’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I know it was a disgusting thing to do but it’s never happened before. I just woke up feeling euphoric,’ Dr Gelder said.

‘I told the Trust I would happily expose myself to Pet Remedy again to confirm the effects, if they though it would be useful. I was absolutely stunned at what happened.

‘I absolutely did not pinch her bottom for sexual gratification.’

Dr Gelder even claimed he ‘would have done the same’ thing to a male nurse had he crossed paths with one that day.

‘I have never behaved in that way before or since,’ he said.

‘Something happened to me on that day and I thought everything was just wonderful and I thought I had superhuman powers.

‘I’ve never been high before or in that state before in my life. It was illogical and irrational. What I did was wrong and I didn’t want to put her through it again.’

Gelder, from Leicestershire, denies sexually motivated misconduct and the hearing continues.
